overflow-hidden","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"absolute inset-0 bg-gradient-to-b from-[var(--accent)]/10 via-transparent to-transparent"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"absolute top-0 left-1/2 transform -translate-x-1/2 w-[800px] h-[400px] bg-[var(--accent)]/5 rounded-full blur-3xl"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"relative max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 pt-12 sm:pt-20 pb-8 sm:pb-12","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"text-center max-w-3xl mx-auto animate-fade-in","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"inline-flex items-center gap-2 px-4 py-2 rounded-full bg-[var(--accent)]/10 border border-[var(--accent)]/20 mb-6","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"w-2 h-2 rounded-full bg-[var(--accent)] animate-pulse"}],["$","span",null,{"className":"text-sm font-medium text-[var(--accent-light)]","children":"Legal Rights Guide"}]]}],["$","h1",null,{"className":"text-3xl sm:text-4xl md:text-5xl font-bold mb-4 leading-tight","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"gradient-text","children":"Know Your Rights"}],["$","br",null,{}],["$","span",null,{"className":"text-[var(--foreground)]","children":"Protect Yourself"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-base sm:text-lg text-[var(--muted)] mb-8 max-w-2xl mx-auto leading-relaxed","children":"An interactive guide to understanding your legal rights in common situations. Knowledge is power ‚Äî learn what protections you have under the law."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex justify-center mb-4","children":["$","$L5",null,{"scenarios":[{"id":"traffic-stop","title":"Pulled Over by Police","icon":"üöó","category":"Criminal / Police","description":"What to know when you're stopped by a traffic officer","rights":[{"title":"Right to Remain Silent","description":"You don't have to answer questions beyond providing your driver's license, vehicle registration, and proof of insurance. In stop-and-identify states, you must provide your name and ID, but you still don't have to answer other questions. Anything you say can be used against you in court.","source":"5th Amendment, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[{"state":"UT","note":"Stop-and-identify state: must provide name and ID upon request"},{"state":"CA","note":"Can remain silent beyond ID; strong privacy protections apply"},{"state":"TX","note":"Stop-and-identify state: must provide ID if lawfully arrested"},{"state":"NY","note":"Can remain silent; provide name and address only if lawfully stopped"},{"state":"FL","note":"Stop-and-identify state: must provide ID"}]},{"title":"Right to Refuse a Vehicle Search","description":"Police cannot search your car without your consent, a warrant, or probable cause (like seeing drugs in plain view). You can clearly say 'I do not consent to a search' even if the officer insists. A dash cam recording of your refusal can protect you later.","source":"4th Amendment - Unreasonable Searches","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong protections against warrantless searches; plainly refuse consent"},{"state":"TX","note":"Can refuse search; officer may ask anyway but you can maintain refusal"},{"state":"NY","note":"Robust 4th Amendment protections; clearly refuse consent in writing if possible"}]},{"title":"Right to Record the Encounter","description":"You have the right to film or record police officers in public spaces while they're performing their duties. This is protected speech. However, don't obstruct the officer, get in their way, or interfere with their investigation.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Explicitly permits recording police in public; strong protections"},{"state":"NY","note":"Recording police is protected; appellate courts have affirmed this right"},{"state":"TX","note":"Can record if you don't interfere; some ambiguity on audio recording"},{"state":"FL","note":"Can record in public, but two-party consent applies to audio in private spaces"}]},{"title":"Right to Know Why You Were Stopped","description":"Officers must tell you the reason for the stop. You can ask 'What am I being stopped for?' If the reason is unclear, note it and mention it to your attorney later. The stop must be based on reasonable suspicion of a traffic violation or crime.","source":"4th Amendment - Terry Stop Doctrine","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to an Attorney","description":"If you are arrested, you have the right to request a lawyer before answering any questions. Say clearly: 'I want to speak to an attorney.' Once you request a lawyer, police must stop questioning you. Do not answer questions after this request.","source":"6th Amendment - Right to Counsel, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[]}]},{"id":"workplace-discrimination","title":"Workplace Discrimination or Harassment","icon":"üíº","category":"Employment","description":"What to know about discrimination and harassment at work","rights":[{"title":"Protection from Discrimination","description":"Your employer cannot treat you unfairly because of your race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. This includes hiring, firing, pay, promotions, and day-to-day treatment. Discrimination based on pregnancy is also illegal. Document all incidents with dates and witnesses.","source":"Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"FEHA expands protection to include sexual orientation, gender identity, and status as transgender"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY Human Rights Law includes sexual orientation, gender identity, and marital status"},{"state":"TX","note":"Follows federal Title VII; no additional state-level protections"},{"state":"FL","note":"Florida Civil Rights Act follows federal model; limited additional protections"}]},{"title":"Right to File a Complaint with EEOC","description":"The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is a federal agency that investigates discrimination complaints. You can file for free. You typically must file within 180-300 days depending on your state. Filing triggers an investigation into your employer's practices.","source":"Title VII and EEOC Authority (29 U.S.C. ¬ß 706)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"180-day deadline; can also file with California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH)"},{"state":"NY","note":"300-day deadline; can file with NY Division of Human Rights instead of EEOC"},{"state":"TX","note":"180-day deadline from discrimination date"},{"state":"UT","note":"180-day deadline; Utah Labor Commission handles state complaints"},{"state":"FL","note":"180-day deadline or 300 days with state civil rights agency"}]},{"title":"Right to Reasonable Accommodation","description":"If you have a disability, your employer must make reasonable changes to help you do your job‚Äîlike flexible scheduling, accessible bathrooms, or equipment modifications‚Äîunless it causes undue hardship. This includes mental health conditions and temporary disabilities. Request accommodation in writing when possible.","source":"Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"FEHA has broader disability definition than federal ADA; more generous accommodations required"}]},{"title":"Protection from Retaliation","description":"Your employer cannot punish you for reporting discrimination, harassment, unsafe conditions, or illegal activity. Retaliation includes termination, demotion, reduced hours, or any negative employment action. Report retaliation immediately to your HR or a lawyer.","source":"Title VII Anti-Retaliation Provision (42 U.S.C. ¬ß 2000e-3)","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Equal Pay","description":"Men and women must receive equal pay for equal work. Equal work means jobs requiring the same skill, effort, and responsibility performed under similar working conditions. If you discover a pay gap, you can file a claim. Keep records of your pay and comparable employees' pay if you know it.","source":"Equal Pay Act of 1963","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"California Equal Pay Act requires equal pay for 'substantially similar' work; broader than federal law"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY law prohibits pay discrimination and requires transparency about pay ranges"}]}]},{"id":"tenant-rights","title":"Landlord Entering Your Rental","icon":"üè†","category":"Housing","description":"What to know about your rights as a tenant in a rental property","rights":[{"title":"Right to Advance Notice Before Entry","description":"Landlords cannot enter your rental without notice except in emergencies (fire, gas leak, police warrant). Most states require 24-48 hours' written notice. Entry is typically allowed only for repairs, inspections, or showings. You can be present during entry and can refuse if notice wasn't given properly.","source":"Implied Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment and State Landlord-Tenant Law","stateVariations":[{"state":"UT","note":"24-hour notice required for entry; 48 hours for non-emergency repairs"},{"state":"CA","note":"24-hour notice required; strong tenant privacy protections enforced"},{"state":"TX","note":"No specific statutory notice requirement for routine entry; reasonableness standard applies"},{"state":"NY","note":"24-hour notice required; tenants have strong privacy rights, especially in NYC"},{"state":"FL","note":"12-hour notice for repairs; 24-hour notice for other purposes"}]},{"title":"Right to Habitable Living Conditions","description":"Your landlord must provide a safe, livable space with functioning heat, hot water, structural integrity, and no hazards like mold or pest infestations. If conditions are unfit to live in, you may have rights to repair-and-deduct, rent withholding, or lease termination. Document problems with photos and written notice.","source":"Implied Warranty of Habitability (common law and state statute)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Habitability standard is strictly enforced; landlords must maintain property in safe condition"},{"state":"NY","note":"Housing Maintenance Code requires landlords meet strict habitability standards"},{"state":"TX","note":"Property Code requires landlord to make repairs timely; repair-and-deduct available"}]},{"title":"Right to Security Deposit Return","description":"Landlords must return your security deposit within a specific timeframe, usually 21-30 days after you move out. Any deductions must be itemized and documented. If your landlord keeps part of your deposit illegally, you can sue for the full amount plus damages and attorney fees.","source":"State Landlord-Tenant Statutes and Deposit Protection Laws","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"21 days to return deposit with itemized deductions; landlord pays damages if non-compliant"},{"state":"NY","note":"30 days to return deposit; strict documentation rules; interest required in some cases"},{"state":"TX","note":"30 days to return deposit; deductions must be itemized; treble damages available for wrongful withholding"},{"state":"UT","note":"30 days to return deposit; landlord must provide itemized deductions"},{"state":"FL","note":"15 days to return deposit; deductions must be itemized; disputes are common"}]},{"title":"Protection from Retaliatory Eviction","description":"Your landlord cannot evict you in retaliation for reporting code violations, habitability issues, or asserting your legal rights. Retaliatory actions are illegal. If you report a problem and then receive an eviction notice soon after, it may be retaliation. Keep records of all complaints and notices.","source":"State Landlord-Tenant Anti-Retaliation Statutes","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong anti-retaliation protections; presumed retaliation if eviction within 180 days of complaint"},{"state":"NY","note":"Anti-retaliation law protects tenants; presumed retaliation within 6 months of complaint"},{"state":"TX","note":"Anti-retaliation protections exist but are narrower than some states"}]},{"title":"Right to Fair Housing","description":"You cannot be denied housing because of your race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability, or familial status. Landlords cannot charge different rent, require different deposits, or set different terms based on protected characteristics. Report violations to HUD or your state's housing agency.","source":"Fair Housing Act of 1968 (42 U.S.C. ¬ß 3601 et seq.)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"FEHA includes sexual orientation, gender identity, and marital status as protected classes"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY Human Rights Law includes source of income and sexual orientation protections"}]}]},{"id":"wrongful-termination","title":"Getting Fired / Wrongful Termination","icon":"üìã","category":"Employment","description":"What to know about your rights when terminated from employment","rights":[{"title":"Protection from Discriminatory Firing","description":"Your employer cannot fire you because of your race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age (40+), disability, or because you reported illegal activity. Discriminatory termination is illegal. If you were fired and suspect discrimination, document the timeline and keep performance reviews, emails, and witness information.","source":"Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA), ADA","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Final Paycheck","description":"You are entitled to all wages you've earned up to your termination date. Timing varies by state‚Äîsome require immediate payment, others allow a final paycheck on the next regular payday. Employers cannot withhold earned wages as punishment. Check your state's specific timeline requirements.","source":"State Wage and Hour Laws and Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Final paycheck due immediately on last day of employment, or earlier if requested"},{"state":"NY","note":"Final paycheck due next regular payday or within a few days at most"},{"state":"TX","note":"Final paycheck due next regular payday"},{"state":"UT","note":"Final paycheck due next payday or within 15 days"},{"state":"FL","note":"No specific state statute; follows federal FLSA (next payday is standard)"}]},{"title":"Right to COBRA Health Insurance","description":"If your employer has 20+ employees, you can continue your group health insurance for up to 18 months after termination by paying the premium yourself (usually about 102% of the employer's cost). COBRA helps bridge the gap until you get new coverage. Your employer must notify you of this right.","source":"Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) of 1985","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"California also has Cal-COBRA for employers with fewer than 20 employees"},{"state":"NY","note":"New York has state continuation coverage options similar to COBRA"}]},{"title":"Whistleblower Protection","description":"You cannot be fired for reporting illegal activity, safety violations, environmental crimes, or other unlawful conduct to government agencies or law enforcement. This protection applies even if you report internally first. Whistleblowers have legal remedies including reinstatement and damages.","source":"Whistleblower Protection Act (OSH Act ¬ß 11(c)), Sarbanes-Oxley, Dodd-Frank","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong whistleblower protections; can include damages and attorney fees"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY Labor Law protects whistleblowers; robust legal framework"},{"state":"TX","note":"Limited whistleblower protections; primarily federal law applies"}]},{"title":"Right to Unemployment Benefits","description":"If you are fired without cause, you can apply for unemployment insurance benefits. You'll receive a percentage of your previous wages for a limited period (typically 26 weeks). Apply immediately after termination. Your employer may contest your claim, but if you were fired unfairly, benefits are likely approved.","source":"State Unemployment Insurance Laws and Federal UI Framework","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Up to 52 weeks of benefits with extensions during high unemployment"},{"state":"NY","note":"Up to 26 weeks of regular UI; extended benefits available in high unemployment periods"},{"state":"TX","note":"Up to 26 weeks of regular benefits; some extensions available"},{"state":"UT","note":"Up to 26 weeks of benefits; apply through Department of Workforce Services"},{"state":"FL","note":"Up to 12 weeks of benefits; rates vary by prior earnings"}]}]},{"id":"jury-duty","title":"Jury Duty Obligations","icon":"‚öñÔ∏è","category":"Civic Duty","description":"What to know about serving on a jury","rights":[{"title":"Right to Serve Without Employer Retaliation","description":"Your employer cannot punish you, fire you, or threaten you for missing work to serve on a jury. This is a protected civic responsibility. If your employer retaliates, you have legal remedies. Bring your jury summons to your employer to prove your obligation.","source":"Jury Systems Improvement Act (28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1875) and State Laws","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Compensation","description":"Federal courts and most state courts pay jurors a small daily fee. Some employers pay your regular wages during jury duty, but this is not required by law. Compensation varies widely by jurisdiction. Longer trials pay more, though the amounts are typically modest.","source":"28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1871 (federal) and State Jury Compensation Laws","stateVariations":[{"state":"UT","note":"Pays $18.50 per day after the first day; first day is unpaid"},{"state":"CA","note":"Pays $15 per day for first 5 days, then $50 per day; private employers may supplement"},{"state":"TX","note":"Pays $6 for the first day, then $40 per day; very low compensation"},{"state":"NY","note":"Pays $40 per day starting day 1; federal courts pay more"},{"state":"FL","note":"Pays $15 per day for first 3 days, $30 per day after"}]},{"title":"Right to Request Postponement","description":"If jury duty is being served at a bad time‚Äîyou have a critical work project, vacation booked, or family emergency‚Äîyou can request to reschedule your service to a later date. Courts are often flexible about this. Submit your request promptly with a valid reason; requests made early are more likely to be granted.","source":"State Court Rules and Judicial Discretion","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Be Excused for Hardship","description":"If jury duty would cause genuine financial or personal hardship‚Äîyou're the sole caregiver, you're self-employed and would lose significant income, or you have a medical condition‚Äîyou can petition to be excused. Courts must consider your circumstances. Provide documentation of hardship.","source":"28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1869 (federal) and State Hardship Exemption Rules","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Courts are relatively generous with hardship excusals; strong worker protections exist"},{"state":"NY","note":"Hardship excusal available; courts weigh financial and personal circumstances"}]},{"title":"Obligation to Appear","description":"Responding to a jury summons is a legal obligation. Failure to appear without valid excuse can result in contempt of court charges, fines up to $1,000, or jail time in serious cases. If you cannot serve, respond to the summons and explain your situation. Ignoring a summons is not an option.","source":"28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1866 and State Court Contempt Laws","stateVariations":[]}]},{"id":"federal-agents","title":"Interacting with Federal Agents (ICE, FBI)","icon":"üõ°Ô∏è","category":"Criminal / Police","description":"What to know about your rights when federal agents approach you","rights":[{"title":"Right to Remain Silent","description":"You do not have to answer questions from ICE, FBI, or other federal agents. Even if they claim they 'just want to talk,' you can remain silent. Anything you say can and will be used against you in immigration, criminal, or other proceedings. Clearly say 'I wish to remain silent' and stick to it.","source":"5th Amendment - Protection Against Self-Incrimination","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Refuse Entry Without a Judicial Warrant","description":"Federal agents need a judicial warrant signed by a judge to enter your home or workplace. An administrative warrant from their own agency is not enough and does not give them the right to enter. You can refuse entry and say 'I do not consent to entry.' An exception exists for exigent circumstances (imminent danger).","source":"4th Amendment - Protection Against Unreasonable Searches, Payton v. New York","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to an Attorney","description":"You have the right to request a lawyer before answering any questions from federal agents. If you say 'I want to speak to a lawyer,' agents must stop questioning. Do not answer follow-up questions after requesting counsel. Request an attorney in clear language, preferably in writing.","source":"6th Amendment - Right to Counsel, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Know If You Are Free to Leave","description":"If approached by federal agents, you can ask 'Am I free to go?' or 'Am I being detained?' If they say you're free to leave, calmly walk away. If they say you're being detained, you're not under arrest yet but they believe they have grounds to hold you. This is still a good time to ask for a lawyer and stop talking.","source":"4th Amendment - Seizure Doctrine","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Not Sign Documents","description":"Never sign anything a federal agent puts in front of you without understanding it completely and consulting a lawyer. This includes immigration forms, consent forms, or 'voluntary' statements. Agents may falsely claim a document is routine or harmless. If you cannot read English, request an interpreter. Never sign if uncertain.","source":"5th Amendment - Due Process; Right to Counsel","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Sanctuary state: limits cooperation between local police and ICE; protections for immigrants"},{"state":"NY","note":"Sanctuary state: NYC has strong protections; limited cooperation with federal immigration enforcement"},{"state":"TX","note":"Non-sanctuary state: local police can cooperate with ICE if they choose"},{"state":"UT","note":"Mixed policies; some cities are more cooperative with ICE"},{"state":"FL","note":"Non-sanctuary state: anti-sanctuary laws; local police cooperation with ICE"}]}]},{"id":"protesting","title":"Protesting / Freedom of Assembly","icon":"üì¢","category":"Civil Rights","description":"What to know about your rights when participating in protests","rights":[{"title":"Right to Peaceful Assembly","description":"You have a fundamental right to gather with others to protest, march, and voice political viewpoints. This is protected as free speech. Peaceful assembly means no violence or property destruction. Police cannot prevent or disperse peaceful protesters without lawful justification (like blocking traffic).","source":"1st Amendment - Assembly and Petition; 14th Amendment","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Protest on Public Property","description":"You can protest on sidewalks, parks, public plazas, and other government property. These are traditional public forums for speech. However, authorities can enforce time, place, and manner restrictions if they apply equally to all groups and don't target your message. Permits may be required for large gatherings but cannot be denied based on viewpoint.","source":"1st Amendment; Public Forum Doctrine","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong protest protections; courts are skeptical of overly restrictive permit requirements"},{"state":"NY","note":"Robust assembly rights; NYC has strong tradition of protest; permit requirements are flexible"},{"state":"UT","note":"Requires permits for large gatherings in some cities; must apply viewpoint-neutral rules"},{"state":"TX","note":"Permits may be required; some restrictions on capital grounds; viewpoint neutrality required"},{"state":"FL","note":"Some anti-protest laws enacted (e.g., HB 1 in 2021 restricts blocking roadways)"}]},{"title":"Right to Photograph and Record in Public","description":"You can photograph and record video and audio of anything visible and audible from a public space. This includes police, protests, and government activities. You do not need permission. However, don't block others, trespass, or interfere with police work. Recording is important documentation of protests and police conduct.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech; Constitutional Right to Record Public Events","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Explicitly permits recording police and public events; strong protections"},{"state":"NY","note":"Court-affirmed right to record police and public events"},{"state":"TX","note":"Can record if you don't interfere; some ambiguity on audio recording"}]},{"title":"Rights if Arrested During a Protest","description":"If arrested at a protest, you still have full constitutional rights. You have the right to remain silent‚Äîdo not answer questions without a lawyer present. Request a lawyer immediately and clearly. Ask why you're being arrested. Do not resist, even if you believe the arrest is unlawful. Challenge it in court later with your lawyer.","source":"5th Amendment, 6th Amendment, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Free Speech","description":"The government cannot restrict your speech based on its viewpoint, message, or content. You can hold signs, chant, and speak about controversial topics. You cannot be arrested for offensive speech alone (with narrow exceptions like true threats). Your speech is protected even if others find it offensive or disagree strongly.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech Clause","stateVariations":[]}]},{"id":"consumer-rights","title":"Consumer Rights","icon":"üõí","category":"Consumer Protection","description":"What to know about consumer protection laws and your rights","rights":[{"title":"Right to Fair Debt Collection","description":"Debt collectors cannot harass you, lie about what you owe, call before 8 AM or after 9 PM, or contact you at work if your employer prohibits it. They cannot threaten jail, garnishment, or arrest if it's not legal. If a debt collector violates these rules, you can sue them for damages. Request written verification of any debt.","source":"Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) of 1977","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"California has additional protections under the Rosenthal Act; strict enforcement against abuse"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY has strong debt collection protections; violations can result in damages"},{"state":"TX","note":"Follows federal FDCPA; limited additional state protections"}]},{"title":"Right to Dispute a Debt","description":"Within 30 days of receiving a debt collector's first letter, you can send a written dispute demanding they prove the debt is valid. They must then provide verification or stop collection efforts. Many debts are unverifiable or belong to someone else. Send disputes by certified mail with return receipt.","source":"Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) ¬ß 809","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"FTC Cooling-Off Rule","description":"If you buy something through a door-to-door sale, telemarketing, or certain other methods, you have 3 business days to cancel and get your money back, no questions asked. The seller must provide written cancellation instructions. This applies even if you agreed to the purchase. Put cancellation in writing.","source":"Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Cooling-Off Rule (16 CFR ¬ß 429)","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Truth in Lending","description":"Lenders must clearly disclose the loan terms, annual percentage rate (APR), finance charges, payment amount, and total amount you'll pay back. All terms must be in writing before you sign. Misleading disclosure of rates or fees is illegal. Compare APRs and terms before committing to a loan.","source":"Truth in Lending Act (TILA) of 1968","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"California has additional disclosure requirements; strong enforcement by Attorney General"}]},{"title":"Lemon Law Protection","description":"If your new vehicle has persistent defects that make it unsafe or unfit for its basic purpose, the manufacturer may be required to replace it or refund your money. Each state has specific rules and timeframes. Defects must be reported and given a chance to be fixed. Documentation of repair attempts is crucial.","source":"State Lemon Laws (varies by state; federal Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act also applies)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Song-Beverly Consumer Warranty Act: covers defects within 18 months or 18,000 miles; strong consumer protections"},{"state":"TX","note":"Covers new vehicles for 24 months or 24,000 miles; manufacturer-friendly with high bar for replacement"},{"state":"NY","note":"Covers defects within 2 years of purchase; requires good faith repair attempts"},{"state":"UT","note":"Covers new vehicles for 24 months or 24,000 miles; requires multiple repair attempts"},{"state":"FL","note":"Covers defects discovered within 24 months; manufacturer-friendly; narrower protections than some states"}]}]}]}]}],"$L6"]}]}]]}],"$L7","$L8","$L9"]}],null,"$La"]}],{},null,false,false]},null,false,false],"$Lb",false]],"m":"$undefined","G":["$c",[]],"S":true}
d:I[3749,["/_next/static/chunks/42209b9d6fad97c0.js"],"default"]
e:I[18929,["/_next/static/chunks/42209b9d6fad97c0.js"],"default"]
f:I[97367,["/_next/static/chunks/ff1a16fafef87110.js","/_next/static/chunks/d2be314c3ece3fbe.js"],"OutletBoundary"]
